pages.body:
# Markdown | [[Markup Languages]]

Markdown is a lightweight markup language for formatting plain text in an easy and intuitive way. It's looks similar to ‚Äòformatting‚Äô conventions which were already in use for plain text e-mail and chat.

## Example

    Heading (1st level)
    ===
    
    Sub-heading (2nd level)
    ---
    
    ### Sub-sub-heading (3rd level, alternative notation)
    
    Just some text purely 
    for demonstration purpose.
    
    We can also make text
    /italic/, **bold** or ___both___
    
    > It actually depends amount of used symbols
    but it does not matter if it is /, * or _
    
    we can also have lists
    * and `code`
    + [links](/0list.bit) [üìé](/186THqMWuptrZxq1rxzpguAivK3Bs6z84o)
    - as well as horizontal rules
    
    ---
    1. numbered
    2. lists work
    3. as well

*results in* [[Markdown (Preview)]]

Images

Admittedly, it‚Äôs fairly difficult to devise a ‚Äúnatural‚Äù syntax for placing images into a plain text document format.

Markdown uses an image syntax that is intended to resemble the syntax for links, allowing for two styles: inline and reference.

Inline image syntax looks like this:

     ![Alt text](/path/to/img.jpg)

     ![Alt text](/path/to/img.jpg "Optional title")

That is:

An exclamation mark: !;
followed by a set of square brackets, containing the alt attribute text for the image;
followed by a set of parentheses, containing the URL or path to the image, and an optional title attribute enclosed in double or single quotes.


## External links

* [official website](http://daringfireball.net/projects/markdown/)
* [wikipedia entry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Markdown)

That is:

An exclamation mark: !;
followed by a set of square brackets, containing the alt attribute text for the image;
followed by a set of parentheses, containing the URL or path to the image, and an optional title attribute enclosed in double or single quotes.

Markdown is a lightweight markup language for formatting plain text in an easy and intuitive way. It's looks similar to ‚Äòformatting‚Äô conventions which were already in use for plain text e-mail and chat.

    Heading (1st level)
    ===
    
    Sub-heading (2nd level)
    ---

Markdown uses an image syntax that is intended to resemble the syntax for links, allowing for two styles: inline and reference.
